War Thunder is a game about Russian medium tanks one shotting everything regardless of their armor or angle, while themselves being all but invulnerable, and a bunch of fanboys defending this mechanic because they seen a WW2 ballistics manual once which they translated from Cyrillic.  The Russian bias in the game is laughable. All the fanboys claiming otherwise are likewise laughable. Get the game if you want to see WWII vehicles drive and fly around with some nice graphics, but unless you play as Russia you will lose most games - the devs even hide the victory stats of the different nations to conceal this fact.  If you want a tank combat game that's actually fun for the most part, give Armored Warfare a try, it's also free, and free from bias toward any particular fighting force. War thunder on the other hand, has sadly gone down hill since launch - the missions for realistic air battles are the same broken pieces of ♥♥♥♥ they were three years ago, and the tank combat is becoming more and more like WoT with toybox sets designed for point-blank street fights that favor Russian tanks over everything else.  But whatever you do, don't point this out to the fanboys, you'll get told to 'get good' 'l2p' etc. I did learn to play - I played Russia with an 80% win rate. Germany? About 30%. America? About the same as Germany, maybe a bit better. But I guess for some reason I'm only good with Russian tanks, and that reason has nothing to do with them being far superior in the game to their counterparts.  Also; you think artillery in WoT is annoying? Imagine having player controlled aircraft dropping bombs directly on you with an actual crosshair that shows exactly where they'll land while they're in third-person view. Thought the spotted indicator from WoT was annoying? Well, same thing here now - added in a recent update you can now see the enemy through solid objects once their spotted. And all of this in Realistic Battles, which used to actually have SOME simulator aspects.   Just got a shiny new heavy tank with good armor? Too bad, you'll be pitted against tanks from between 3 to 18 or even 30 years in the future using Vietnam war era ammunition against your WW2 solid shot shooting ♥♥♥ thereby making you nothing more than an easy target. Unless you're playing as Russia, of course.  Not to mention the various pay to win vehicles, which are actually available to every nation, but I guess that's how you're supposed to win against Russia, amirite? And my god, are they ever pay to win. Especially the planes. But especially the tanks. But ESPECIALLY the planes. Want an american rocket ship armed with cannons that climbs as good as the actual german rocket fighter but 2 tiers earlier? They have you covered. Want a tank with practically the same armor as even the absurd German designs which never actually even existed evan as a fully built prototype - the maus - but are still in the game because otherwise German endgame would have nothing to fight the 70's era Russian bs outside of 1 medium tank? Just $50!   I mean, they have the me 262 fighting the mig 17. That should tell you everything you need to know right there.

Ok, It's been a while since a last wrote a review for a game, but i guess now would be the best time to write one myself. War thunder is my second most played game, and i think it's quite fun, it's got tanks planes boats coming out and a new game mode coming where all of them can fight against eachother on huge maps kind of like planetside 2. Any one person can enjoy war thunder, if you can put up with one thing. One thing alone is what ruins this game, the community. All of the talk of 'Russian bias' and horrible match making is, in most ways, wrong. I'm sorry if you're butt hurt, but there is no russian bias, to the point where it's become a bit of meme to say 'Russian bias' at everything. Though some people still take this seriously. but in reality, tanks are not dominated by russians, if anything they are dominated by germans, and in some cases the U.S too (M-18's and M6A1's). The only time russians really do good is around the third tier (T-34/85 and KV-220 kappa), after that it's really skill that tips the balance of a game.  First off, my point on the community, oh god the community. All they do is complain left and right, gaijin fixes something, they complain more, etc. I can't think of once were the community of this game actually credited gaijin for their game, that being said, there are some people who are out there just trying to enjoy the game, yet theres still the people who say 'But thers 2 much russian bias'. Yeah, i can get a little mad when i'm in my Tiger I and a T-34/85 kills me, but it's really all they're doing, i can just respawn, and get him back. Higher tiers can also be quite annoying in the 'russian bias' regard, mainly due to the addition of the ZSU-57-2 and the IT-1, which i hate just as much as the next man, but i always remember 'it's tier V, all i gotta do get good and move on'. Sure, those tanks can be cancer, but MAUS is a very good counter to these tanks, that is, if you're in Tier V.  My second point will be on the matchmaking, something i myself can say can be a bit annoying. Post war tanks against Tiger II's may sound a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, yet almost every game i play as russia with the allies at 6.7, we lose, guess theres too much russian bias for them to win games. though early tiers are acutally quite well balanced, when people start going up against post war tanks is when they complain the most. There is one thing i wish gaijin could REALLY work on, that being better communication with the community. I've been waiting so long for the T-32 to get to 7.0 rather than 7.3 (Trust me, it makes a huge difference) that it kind of pisses me off, though, they have been listening more and more lately (some small examples being fixing jet RB for 7.0's and nerfing the panther II's reload in arcade).  Then there's Aircraft. Planes are a bit of a mixed bag, RB is for someone looking for a more realistic take on an air battles, where as arcade is your go to gamemode for grinding and having a bit of fun. That being said, there are some problems with it. Some of the planes gaijin has been adding have been quite over powered for a while, then nerfed, then still getting called OP by the o-so-positive community, this mainly being planes like the TU-4 and BV-238 for example. Neither of these planes are that great anymore due to balancing of how they work (TU-4 now facing jets, BV-238 seems to be easier to kill for me.) which is what really makes planes something any new player should go to first.  Lastly, Since i've seen it i couple of times in other reviews, i want to touch on the CEO and his handling of the hack that (From what i can tell) isn't really in the game anymore from early on this year. What he did was stupid, nothing more then stupid, then i hear about what they did in regards to the russian youtuber who pointed out flaws in the game, I dought this will happen again after they were exposed, and considering i've seen big youtubers point out flaws and not get their channels deleted, it seems the CEO has finnally stopped drinking vodka for breakfast.  Over all i can say that war thunder is a one of a kind game here on steam, and that it really is something that a love to play, so if you're interested flying famous WW2 and cold war aircraft, or duking it out in heavy weight panzers, or even Sailing the fair seas in you're shiny schnell boat. this game can be your key to enjoyment. Best of luck, and see you in the battlefields of war thunder. (Cheese level overload)

I have a LOT of time and even a fair amount of $$ into this game and there are a few things to take away from it. 1, In it's very basic form it feels like a scam. It doesn't feel as if the devs actually cared about the history or about the player enjoyment as much as they cared about profit. The game constantly asks you to buy things as it is the definition of a pay to win game.( actually you aren't even gaurenteed a win if you pay so think of it as 'pay to play better'). 2, I love the flying mechanics and the feel of the game. It can easily make the inner kid of anyone come out. 3. THIS GAME IS SUCH A GRIND! This game is the longest game knowen to man. Not in a good way because if you every invest time into one of the really nerfed nations such as America, then you end up in a grind that will last 10000 hrs+ before you even finish the first tech tree. I wish the game was faster so you could constantly be moving through the progress of the tech tree and onto other nations. 4. It feels as if some nations are nerfed so that the nations with large and new playerbases such as america wish attracts younger and less experinced audineces to be less equipped and thus spend more money. In total, this game is very fun, it is also very very agrovating as whenever you start to have fun, you get held back or the moment gets ruined by some pay to win/unballenced aspect.

You wanna good WWII combat simulator? I am sure you do, thats why you are here, isn't it? You want that game to be well balanced too, right? Yes I am sure you do You want a game with no nation bias? Of course! Then why the hell are you looking at War Thunder? Seriously, go play one of the Red Orchestra games, they may not have planes and they may not be free, but they are cheap and have really good tank gameplay that is both fun and balanced and still maintain historical accuracy. In short basically everything War Thunder is not.  The first thing you notice with War Thunder is what I call the 'shell', which is basically what you perceive, the shell is probably the best part of War Thunder. The graphics are absolutely beautiful, all the models for the tanks and planes are fully detailed down to every nook cranny and bolt; but then you play the game, the game is pretty fun at first but once you hit tier II-III, thats when the game starts to go down hill and that is when you really and I mean REALLY start to notice something is incredibly wrong with the Russian planes/tanks. Just to put it into perspective (this is a true story by the way): My Tiger tank was unable to penetrate the front of a T-34 at less than 40 meters and he was directly in front of me, he ended up killing me because the Tiger really didn't have over 100 mm thick armor and a ridculous gun, thats just 'western propaganda' according to gaijin (I dont think they actually said that but it wouldn't suprise me if they did because that is their reasoning behind anything that is not Russian being under powered) Another example would be the time I went into a head on fight with a Yak-9 in my Typhoon mkIB (Very historically accurate I know) and naturally I killed him since 4 20mm machine guns hurt, but while his plane was a flaming and wingless wreck he managed to get ONE last cannon round out which caused both my wings and my tail to fall off and my plane was a flaming wreck just like his. Now that that is out of the way; remember how I mentioned 'the shell'? Well, the shell is not really there for most people, and while this problem has been delt with in the past it still exists, but what is it? Well, all those lush trees, bushes and grass can just disappear if you go into the options menu and turn down your graphics, and while on your screen you are very well camouflaged in your STUG III some Russian guy across the map sees you with your pants down looking like a drooling idiot. So how is the game developing you might ask? Well, the devs are just adding content and not really fixing anything, and the drooling middle school-age masses that is the War Thunder community is okay with this. Speaking of the community, lets talk about them. Basically the type of brain you'll be playing with are ones that are not developed enough to use logic and reason and if the match does not go in their way they will spam the chat all caps screaming at everyone who is still alive, its to the point where reporting these people is usless since there is so many of them and Gaijin doesn't do anything about them, thats why they are too afraid to fix the bushes and trees problem, they are too afraid to loose a handful of players.  There are so many more things I could go over, but there are other reviews out there that will explain those things I failed to mention in greater detail than me. I will end on this note: I do not recommend War Thunder to anyone. There are so many promises that are unfulfilled it makes DayZ look like a finished product. And the sad part is: This used to be a pretty good game, but it has been on a steady decline ever since before they added tanks a couple years ago Well, goodbye my friends, thank you for reading this review and I hope it helped
A good game driven into the ground by greed and imbalance.

First off, I have more than 1000hrs in War Thunder, I played long before it was avaiable on Steam.   War Thunder was one of my favourite ever games, then slowly but surely the greatness was wiped out - patch after patch of disastrous decisions has run this game in to the ground. I used to play it every day, now I fire it up once a month for a single game and then leave after noting nothing has changed.   The Battle Rating compression is the single worst thing they have done in this game (among many), it seems implemented just to frustrate players in to buying premiuim and premium currency just to get to a stage where they can actually compete at their Battle Rating.  War Thunder as a concept is incredible and indeed it was for a few years, but the last year in particular it has been ruined by the matchmaking system and the devs ignoring community concerns with strict policing on the forms. Do not get sucked in to spending money on this game.

UPDATE: Patch 1.53 -   Once again, this game is a lot like playing ping pong against Gump. ♥♥♥♥ flying at you from all directions. It sometimes takes me back to the brush back in 'nam... you never knew when Charlie was gonna take a pot shot at the column. Cept in this game, you get it from both ends, gotta watch out for your own team so they don't shoot you in the back.   I kid you not, I've been in a few matches where my own team dealt more damage to my plane(s) then the enemy. It takes skill and cat-like reflexes to dodge teammates that come out of nowhere and fly right into you, or enemy rammers for that matter. Dodging teammates is as important a skill as dodging enemy fire and planes.   Twice the challenge, twice the fun. I prefer to stay in 3.0 or below, because I gotta say it, those Ruskie biplanes sure are fun to fly. (I-153 with 20mm cannons, AND 8 rockets?!?!?)   Now that I got my legs back, I can finally use the rudders again!   By the way, that low bridge with just 5-10 feet of clearance on that one stage with the rivers CAN be flown under. Just saying. Did it twice in a row this one match, trying to see if I could get the guy on my tail to try to do it and crash.   He didn't try though. Oh well, as I always say, y'can't kick ♥♥♥ and have 2 feet on the ground at the same time. In War Thunder though, you can't kick ♥♥♥ while you're on the ground, period.   Obviously, I'm only reviewing the Aircraft half of the game, I did try the tanks, but I for one, find the aircraft battles way more fluid and fast paced.   Its hard to beat flying at below tree top level at 400-500mph, wingtips brushing the branches.

WarThunder is a complicated game to judge. If we purely focus on the game itself - it's a solid game; bugs are minimal and mechanics are well thought through in the different gamemodes.  Now, what lets this game down is its developers. Gaijin have truly created something unique and accessible to the games market, by pioneering a mouse system for flight control that works well. On the other hand, Gaijin's priorities are in entirely the wrong places at the moment (v,1.37-v.1.39). Gaijin are investing more time towards addings new aircraft, new ground vehicles, and events, rather than going back and improving what they've already created.  As a result of this, we see flight/damage models which are either unfinished, or not correct. This truly is a game-changing factor when playing realistic/full simulator battles, since those difficulty levels require extensive knowledge of your plane, as well as the enemies; what they can do, how they can perform, how to approach different enemies/situations, etc etc.  On top of this, Gaijin seem to have developed a weakness, in giving into the communities desires opposed to their own; in most circumstances where this is the case, the group with the loudest voice often gets their way. This has become even more clear in patch 1.39, seeing USA and Germany gain planes which further give them advantage, whilst also seeing nerfs to the USSR, barely any changes to high tier British, and unecessary nerfs to Japan.  Finally, the match-making system is fundementally broken. At high tiers, you have the issue of 'super-props' fighting weak jets. Higher up the chain that this, you see very weak jets fighting strong ones. At the bottom of the scale, you see reserve planes (the first few planes you get) fighting against planes of tier 1; although this is not massively imbalanced, for those attempting to learn the game, it may become frustrating.  At the end of the day though, should you try WarThunder? Yes, why wouldn't you, it's free? Just remember, although it's not pay-to-win, it is pay-to-progress.  UPDATE: 1.41 has seen the release of ground units - but more appropriate to this review, some previous mistakes have been rectified. High tier USSR (Tier V) appears to be on the mend, with recent buffs to the Mig-15. As well as this, the German Me.163 has had its battle rating increased, meaning it can no longer pick on Mig-9's and Meteor F.3's.  On another note, it is slightly worrying seeing how many mini-patches are being released for the ground forces compared to the aviation forces. To be honest, this is hardly suprising, seeing as average player numbers have gone from around 30k-45k per night, to around 90k.

[WARNING: TL;DR]  Relevant parts are highlighted!  (EDIT: I have 915 hours in-game, just recently added it to Steam)   Blew up a Yak-9U with rockets going 500+mph 8/10 will play all day long  This game is fantastic! If you love flying and don't want to pay for it, this game might be for you. There are Arcade, Realistic and Simulator Battles all with increasingly realistic flight models (FMs). There are, however, many problems with the game, and thiss will not be the most glowing review.  - FMs are HEAVILY skewed towards Russian planes, decidedly away from American planes. The devs have no intention of changing this.   - ALL of the nations have their day in the sun.  Whoever it is that balances the planes at Gaijin, is permanently drunk. When they make one plane in the tier better, they not only do so with a heavy hand, they also do it without regard as to how other planes compare to the plane being altered.  If your plane sucks today, wait until the next patch, when it will either become SUPER MEGA AWESOME or be slightly better than before. When I started, it was Americans that sucked, then Japanese, then Brits, then Germans, then Americans again, then Brits and Japs, then Germans, now Americans again. Russia waffles between 1st and 3rd best.  History is glanced at and then altered to fit the Motherland.  -  Russian Bias.  Those Russkies can skip bullets with their wooden-skinned planes, turn nearly as sharp as a spit, climb like helicopoters, are faster than God and typically carry (historically accurate) heavy cannons.  The weaknesses of Russians? They overheat really bad and carry just a tad bit of ammo. Not really a problem when all you need to do is nail your first few shots and keep the throttle down.  - Gaijin Hates America.   - Instead of fixing major issues, like FM accuracy or excessive Arcade ramming, they simply introduce more planes.  Not only that, they introduce more PREMIUM planes. Because nobody should have too much fun, playing for free. Not too terrible, however, because I shoot down those Premium planes regularly.  -They don't really announce what they are fixing and nobody knows where the development is going.  Gaijin fails at communication , although Russian players seem to get plenty of feedback. (I resisted the idea of Russian bias until I got my friend's Russian girlfriend to submit a ticket in Russian, instead of English. Got a reply 30 minutes later).  - The grind can take an eternity, and they aren't making it any easier to get the next plane.  At around Tier 3, you will stall out HARD on leveling up, which is some serious crap. I just got my first jet after about 18 months of playing and I only paid maybe $40 total for crew training and a single Premium plane. The Prem planes aren't particularly special, but crew training makes every plane you get have a better chance of surviving.  - If you only play Arcade, the you'll think whole universe wants to kill just YOU.  I only play Realistic and sim, because I have a greater chance of running away. There is nothing wrong with running away, if you have time to spare, but in Arcade, everyone is in a small meatgrinder and players that play too long will begin ramming. Plus they all have maxed crews and shoot the biggest cannons.  Arcade is heavily biased towards cannon size and doesn't care at all for the plane itself.  Might as well make it all the same damn plane with ultra-cannons.  If you can get past these flaws and accept they won't be fixed, it's actually pretty fun, and the planes look great. It supports Oculus Rift and has SSAO, as well.  The combat is super fun if you aren't flying the current underdog nation (often but not always America) and Russians aren't unbeatable, just unrealistically powerful .  They don't have BS like 'Premium Ammo' or other pay-to-win crap.  People gripe about it being play-to-win. It isn't!! Paying does help, but you can do  just fine  by properly leveling your crew.

After having put over 1150 hours into this game I believe I owe to it to write a review for it. Now, I wouldn't put so much time into a game if I didn't love it... and I still do. It truly is a great game, competitive/challenging, fun with GREAT graphics...and I admit I am a sucker for good graphics. I have played countless tank and plane battles and here's my take on some of the things people in the reviews tend to complain about:  Expensive premium items/premium account: I tend to agree that the regular prices for premium accounts and items are expensive. With that said, they have sales twice a year offering 50% discounts on premium accounts and items, and with the discount, the price is actually very manageable. The way I look at this is for most of the games that I buy for $60 - $70 CAD, I'm lucky if I put over 100 hours into them. Having spent over 1150 hours on this game, I feel like I owe much more than $70 to the developers for continually supporting this game, so when it comes to cost of the premium account - yes it may be expensive, but at the end of the day, if you play this game as much as I do, which is a lot, it is actually very justifiable in my opinion.   Toxic player base: Yes it is, I believe this game would have been even more enjoyable if players were friendlier and worked together. This game is mostly full of lone wolves doing their own thing and have no understanding of teamwork. This is definitely a negative, and aside from greatly changing the game mechanics, the devs are not able to do a whole lot to change this, so this is here to stay.   Terrible Matchmaker: Yes it is. This is my biggest issue with the game and has been ever since they overhauled the matchmaker 2 years ago. This plagues both tank and plane battles and it just makes 0 sense. When you're in an IS-1 in the same map as a T-10, you may as well pack your bags and go home. I remember soon after the big update, hordes of players jumped on the forums to let the developers know that they screwed up, and 2 years later... nothing has changed. It seems the developers stopped listening to the players and are just doing what they want...which is fine since it's their game, but is also unfortunate to all the players that have been complaining for the past 2 years.   This game is thankfully not pay-to-win. Having a premium account definitely does help to reduce on the amount of grinding required, but as long as you're enjoying yourself and not thinking of it as grinding, you'll enjoy the experience much more. At the end of the day, people have to remember that this is a BUSINESS and as a business, they have to make revenue. If you're out here spending hundreds of hours on a free game, and are complaining about getting a premium account pop up every once in a while, then you are likely very young and have no understanding of economics.   There is much more potential to this game if the devs got back on track and began listening to the players again, but it hasn't happened in the last 2-3 years, so I don't have a reason to believe they will change their ways anytime in the near future. Nevertheless, I believe the pros in this game greatly outweigh the cons, and I would still recommend this game to anybody.   8/10

Let me start off by saying War Thunder CAN be fun. However, you have to keep two things in mind in order for it to be so.   Firstly, you cannot expect a balanced fight. Certain aircraft and tanks that are the supposed same battle rating (and therefore roughly as powerful) seriously overshine the others. Likewise, the matchmaking system does not match up equal forces; not only can player numbers differ, but composition can be so slewed that one side doesn't stand a chance.  Secondly, you cannot expect to win. Although this is a team-based game, there is very little reason for the majority of players to actually play that way. If you're in a squad with friends, you can get bonus points for sticking near each other and getting a kill. Other then that, there is no reason to support the rest of your team versus trying to get kills. One kill will net your more of a gain then winning the battle; as such, rarely will you find a player who will try to win.  There is a lot more things in the game I could complain about (such as the horrid modification research grind, the silly repair times, and the monstrous amount of time they expect a player to throw into events for paltry awards), but if you're having fun, the rest doesn't really matter. If you can play with the two things I mentioned in mind and have fun, you'll like this game. If you can't, you probably should pass on it.

After about four-five hundred hours of play, I thought it time to review this game. And because this is a full release, I'm bringing full judgement onto it. My rating is based on main key factors,EG graphics level,runability on potatoes(bad computers), General playstyle,and other important aspects. Smaller side aspeccts are factored in aswell,but weighted lower. Onwards with the review! Number 1 weighted aspect.   Playability and Feel. This game feels like what it is trying to do. When locked in dogfights I feel like i am flying a, well, flying machine. I use mouse aim,and love it. The aircraft feel like they have weight unlike another warplane game. WorldOfWarPlanes *cough* 9/10 for this section  Runability on a poor computer like mine. This game runs excellently on a potato of a computer. OK,my fps capped at 20ish in combat,but what do you expect? This is weighted a tad lower in overall. 8/10 for hiccups.  Physics-type things! I LOVE games that feel realistic. I'm not skilled enough for full real yet,but overall these aircraft (and tanks) handle excellently in arcade and historical. Aircraft when flown skillfully enough,cut through air like a knife in warm butter. 9.3 Repeating.  Graphics. Hardest to detail. Ultra LOW settings give it a crisp,arcade-y feel,and high graphics immerse you into the world. The smoke and flame effects are gorgeous even on low. 10/10 would get shot down looking at perty fiiiireeee. 8.5/10 for some irregularities.  Misc. These are the low weighted things that people who nitpick about detail should read. First, Microtransactions. -10/10. You can throw money at the screen to advance. Glitches. My potato has a rendering glitch when swapping to other players after being shot down,they appear to be flipping out all over. Glitches lower the overall score by rougly .25 points.  FINAL RATING: All nitpicks aside,this is an amazing combat simulator. I am hyped for when warships are announced. The Mighty Wolf final score is 8.75 out of 10. There are some bad things,and no game is perfect. I love the gameplay of just dogfighting with people. TL;DR This game is amazing get it Mighty Wolf,Signing out!

TL;DR: frustratingly fun.  The main basis of the game is that you start with crappy vehicles and as you use them, you gain research points to invest toward unlocking your next vehicle. In addition, each vehicle itself uses research points to unlock upgrades for better usability. Eventually you break into the next tier of vehicles which enables you to fight better and stronger opponents.  However, this brings me to my chief complaint: balancing issues. It is all too frequent that you might be using lower tier 2 aircraft or tanks and you would think that it would pit you up against high tier 1's or other tier 2, but it seemingly loves to throw in maybe some higher tier vehicles. This very frequently stacks the game such that a lower tiered player would struggle to defend oneself. This is pretty frustrating in aircraft, but with tanks it can cause frequent rage quits when someone's vehicle is simply unable to pierce the armor of upscaled tanks on the opposing team.  The game has adapted a nice variation between arcade and realism modes. If you're looking to play the simulator mode, aside from a cyclic and throttle you're pretty much SOL in terms of cockpit configuration. However, the mechanics and physics of the game are relatively high quality. For example, each aircraft and tank model is loaded with a series of hitboxes which determine what kind of damage takes place on the vehicle making fuel leaks possible, weapon damage possible, engine damage, instant pilot kills, etc.  Fun game. Worth trying. May or may not be for you.

This is the best WW II air combat game there is and the best part about it is that its generally free. You can easily go your whole life without unloading a ton of money on War Thunder. That being said, I do suggest that you buy some sort of something at some point so as to support the development of the game. anyway, this game is awesome. It combines simulation with easy controls and it does so very well. There are a few various game modes that very in realism and subsequent difficulty. Arcade mode offers you quick and simple playability with various respawns and a nifty indicator that shows you the estimated strike point of your ordanence. Realistic mode combines semi realistic controls in a historical situation. You are pitted against enemy aircraft in a semi historical battle and real world map. Simulator battels are for the advanced pilots only. it combines near perfect flight models with a situation that will have you constantly zooming in on planes trying to figure out if they are hostile. In this mode you have to be careful of flat spins and stalls as well as trying not to get shot down. It is a grueling mode with the horrors of bad team coordination and friendly fire ending in your demise.  all in all it is a very good game and I definitely recommend it.  -DogSpit

OK, seeing an awful lot of hate for this game in the reviews, but the vast majority of them are along the lines of 'Waah, update 1.37 totally changed things, it was waaaaay better before, now my progress is slower, I hate Gaijin' etc etc without telling us whether the game is, you know, fun? So after a few days playing I figured I might try to redress the balance. I didn't play this game pre-1.37 so I've got nothing to QQ about, and the question is, if you've never tried the game before and you're wondering whether it's worth the download, the answer is a resounding... YES!  First things first - the game looks GORGEOUS. Absolutely beautiful scenery, great models (I'm no aviation nerd, but they sure look a hell of a lot better than my benchmark flight sim, Mig Alley Ace) and frankly one of the reasons I've enjoyed playing bombers is it's just awesome flying at 5000m en route to the enemy airfield admiring the scenery for a few minutes without any annoying fighters buzzing you. Even at 10 feet above the ground, everything looks stunning.  Secondly, game-play - another huge tick. Want intense 300mph action as you scream around 180 degree turns trying to get a bead on that Nazi a-hole that's peppering your tail? It's got that in spades. Prefer the leisurely cruise at high altitude dropping precision bombs from several miles up? Check. Dive-bombing. Torpedoing ships. Strafing ground convoys. You can have several planes per mission, so you can go for all fighters, fighters and bombers, fighters-bombers-torpedos, whatever you prefer. Massively adds to the variety, and therefore longevity, of the game.  Next - is it p2w? A resounding.... no! Buying Gold Eagles, the premium currency, will speed things up massively, but 2 points need to be made.  Firstly, what's the rush?? Yes, if you spend hundreds of *currency* you could complete all the research and race onto level 5 planes quite quickly, but why? It's not that if you level really quickly you can have some super-powered jet fighter to poon all the crappy bi-planes... Level 1 planes fight in level 1 matches and level 5 planes fight in level 5 matches, and is there really any need to whizz through the first 4 levels in a week flat so you can spend the rest of the lifetime of the game at max level? For example, after about 3 afternoons of battles I got my first level 2 plane, so I can now enter either level 1 or 2 matches. Am I crying myself to sleep at night because I won't be entering level 5 matches for quite a while? Not at all.  Secondly, are the rich kids who spent hundreds of bucks totally pooning the opposition? Absolutely not. Again, if you buy premium content, you'll advance through the levels quicker, but you won't be dominating the level you're currently in. [There are a number of planes that are only available for cold hard cash, but so far I've yet to encounter them in-game, and to be totally frank a skillful pilot with a plane available to anyone is going to kick the ♥♥♥ of an unskilled pilot with a cash-only plane any day!]  So it's NOT p2w, it's GREAT fun, it looks gorgeous, and it's FREE ffs!!! If you played before 1.37 and the update cancelled your hard-earned research or reduced it or whatever, that's not good and we should all keep a close eye on the devs for nasty surprises in the future, but don't use that as a reason to put off new players: and if you haven't played before and you're wondering, is this worth my time downloading, is this fun? Then ignore the old-skool grumblers and give it a go, if you have the slightest interest in flight-sims you'll have a blast!   I'll end by giving this f2p game the highest praise I can... I love the idea of getting something totally for free, and often approach f2p games with a sort of 'come on, force me to spend cash so I can resent you' attitude. With War Thunder, I'm thinking after a few days play of buying a premium pack, not because I feel I have to because I'm getting pooned in-game and cash is the only way to prevent that, but because I've been given a fabulous game totally free and I actually don't resent giving the devs some reward for producing such a great game - I don't think that's happened to me since LOTRO. And isn't that exactly how f2p should work??

Please fix the matchmaking system and make the russians less over powered Gaijin, Until then my review will remain a negative one.

I started this game about 1.7 years ago. I loved it to peices (I don't use Steam for it) and am sadder every patch when they leav what made it great. In tanks, if you fire a shell and it hits, it has a chance (Not based on logic of any kind) to do some damage. Here is the table of it.  Russian German American British  85% 38% 25% ?  In planes some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shoots you on takeoff and you are left with 7 minutes of not being able to fly that plane again.  The grind is abysmal. You want a jet without paying $300 and taking up 4 hours every day for 5 months? (That is no exxagerated BTW) Well look elsewhere.  Jets are horribly imbalanced anyway. The Me 262 is whooped by all the later jets that get whooped by the later still jets. They have literally no advantages. Except the Me 262, it has the most raw stopping power in game. (But it is so innacurate, and if you get some hits a 'sparkle sparkle' happens, and your 30mm HE shells do nothing)  Modules are another pain in the ♥♥♥♥. Mostly at higher tiers, like 4 and especially 5, these modules are often essential, and a plane with them can feel like a differen plane to one that lacks them, even if they are the same type. This is compounded by the fact that at higher tiers these can become very difficult indeed to get.   Also, there is often very screwed up match making. Tiger 1s, for instance, face IS-2 1944s in most matches, and simply cannot penetrate them front on, no matter how lucky and well placed it is. The IS-2 1944 on the other hand, can blow the Tiger half way to heaven in one badly placed shot.   That and simular scenerio is far too common. Someone, decided that He 51 biplanes that barely exceed 250mph in a vertical dive, are great matches against P-40s that can easily reach that speed in level flight, have 3x as many guns with 6x the damage done.  Bombers are also very screwed up. If a fighter looks at you your stuffed. Any cabbagehead can send any bomber in flames to it's doom in almost any fighter with minimal effort. Don't even bother with escorts, fighter pilots are always too busy murdering enemy bombers.   A minor note, some guns sound funny. (This can be amusing) German 7.92 MGs sound like telephones!  But seriously, this game can feel like extortion if you can't commit thousands of hours in a re;atively short period. I think I have played 2000+ hours, You would expect me to have every plane with all the bells and wistles? Nope. I only have 2 jets, and that's because I paid for faster RP.  The forums reflect this, so deeply routed are these issues that no-one contradicts them, and thus conversations devolve into 'This is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥! That is historically stupid and not fun at all!'  Hell, I coined the phrase 'Snakers and Ladders in 3D' simply because of all the luck. As long as you have a tiny bit of skill, you can get crazy ♥♥♥♥ because of RNG. (Random number generator)  And you know what? It has 6 modes, Tank Arcade, Air Arcade, Realistic Air, (Don't let 'realistic' fool you - it's not) Realistic tanks, Simulator Air, Simulator Tanks. In 'Simulator' and 'Realistic' modes (Often refered to as Arcade++) sometimes teams will not resemble any air force. I remember a game in my He 112*, I shot down a P-36 (American prewar fighter) and on the enemy team was also a Japanese bomber and two Spitfires, one on each team. Oh, and it was in Guandalcanal. (Pacific island, it was fought over in 1942 in a massive battle)  In tanks this is even worse, (This is Realistic and Simulator Modes) with T-34s fighting Panzer IVs in D-Day. Urban maps are also the norm, no tank battles were fought in cities IRL, and there is NO infantry. NOT ONE SOLDIER. Even in Stalingrad.  As Call of Duty, I rate it 3/10. As Simulator, I give it 1/10, for looking realistic for the first 7 seconds of play.  *German fighter, never saw service besides a prototype tank busting in the Spanish Civil War

TL:DR: Horrible match making makes the game borderline unplayable for new player if you don't pay up.  The match making in this game is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. When you see on tier 2 matches people between rank 5 and rank 150, you just gotta pray that the high tier people are on yours side, as otherwise you just get obliterated. Then there is this Crew upgrading mechanic in the game to make players that have been playing the game longer than you to be statistically better than new on every aspect.   So, if two exact same tanks, other with fresh crew, other with fully upgraded crew, aims each other at same weak spot and fires at the same time, the upgraded crew wins 95% of the time. Even if neither are destroyed on initial shot, the upgraded crew recovers from the hit faster, repairs the damage faster, reloads the gun faster, and you can imagine the rest.  This would be totally OK if these two players wouldn't meet on the battlefield, but the horrible matchmaking makes new player's experience pretty much like I just said.  Obviously you can just throw money to Gaijin and get better tanks and upgrade your crew faster to make your life less miserable which is their business plan, but is the game really worth it?

There are lots of really great things about this game that amount to nothing for one reason: mouse aim. Mouse aim is a control scheme option that is ostensibly for newbies and those without joysticks. In practice, however, it removes every ounce of skill required to fly in this game. What it actually does is has the computer control your roll pitch and yaw in order to steer the plane towards where your mouse cursor is pointing. The end result of this is that people using this control scheme have an absolutely massive advantage over people playing with either joysticks or other control schemes.  This is the same as mouse+keyboard vs controller for a shooter, where the mouse has a very significant advantage over the controller. The problem is that the mouse aim control scheme does not, in any way, feel like a flight sim. It's more akin to early 90s arcade rail shooters with planes.  This control scheme ruins the game. There are modes where you can play where mouse aim is not allowed, but aside from the fact that no one plays these modes, they are nearly impossible to play without some sort of head tracking device.  This game has a great deal of potential but is ruined by the devs putting in what is essentially an aimbot.

With the 300 long hours playing this game, I can conclude that:   Pros: - Fun when you're doing well - Great graphics - Extremely Optimized - Free if you don't want to rank up faster   Cons: - Broken rank system. (Continues to break as planes are added) - Takes forever to rank up and earn research points which are used to buy and upgrade planes/tanks - American planes don't have completely correct flight models. (P-51D's to be exact) - 50. cal machine guns are worthless for air targets - Damage models are complete ♥♥♥♥ most of the time - Easy to get angry and rage  - People steal your kill (Happens very often) - Rockets are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t - Bomber spam (somewhat fixed)  Summary: War Thunder is a hard game to get the hang of. If you know nothing about planes and tanks, it will take you some time. Don't waist your hard drive space if you get easily ♥♥♥♥♥♥ by ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. If you can handle a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and don't rage because of it, try this game. Even though it's been out for a few years now, it still has great potential to be something really good. Gaijin just hasn't figured out how to do that yet.

Changes to this game in recent patches and the last 6 months have changed it from a leading arcade flight game/sim to a steaming pile of waste. The matchmaking has been ruined and is totally ahistorical. Me262 fighting F86Fs every game, He112Bs facing La5s and P47Ds, Fw190A5 facing the F8F-1 Bearcat. Every single game. No, thank you.   The Developers told us that balancing aircraft by introduction date is 'not physically possible', citing the example that the B17 and Russian I-15 biplane were introduced in the same year. The community isn't listened to, the value of premium currency has decreased, aircraft paid for with real money get neutered and changed without warning or explaination.  Don't waste your time.

Warthunder in my opinion is a great game due to it's realism, amount of fun, and evergrowing selection of aircraft and land vehicles. A large variety of computers can play this due to how many different things one can change in the settings. The amount of game modes are ok, but this is made up for in the amount of different battles and settings one can engage in. The game dislays beautiful graphics and detail of the landscape at max settings. The game is also in my opinion, challenging because the game is dependent upon skill mostly. In Warthunder, a good player who exhibits high skill in completing the objective will more than likely progress 2-4 times as fast as a player who is the opposite. Warthunder is a great game that is being updated frequently and should be tried out by players who display interest in WWII, armored vehicles, and/or aircraft of the WWII era.

TL;DR at the end + some hints for beginners.  WarThunder is great and easy for some quick action. Its visually pleasing and the extended damage-modell allows for some skill and tactics: Be sure to look up the ammo-types at the forum and/or wiki - theres a lot to learn ... or just stay with the default ammo which will most of the time be a good Allrounder.   So its a fine game, but theres something else I would advise: Know when to exit and make a pause. The game can be very infuriating when you run into situations where there is not much you can do or when you have some bad luck with your team. Its best to get off and do something else than to start spray acid everywhere, like some do.   What you will also notice eventually: Whining about certain races and/or vehicles. Some of that is true: War Thunder is -not- a symmetric game. Certain vehicles will be better than most of its competitioners. Thats just how it is and its hard to avoid with balancing. I would advise to simply learn about those vehicles and use them yourself - there is no shame in that.  Some of those complaints seem to just stem from people not knowing how to play their race, though. How to angle your armor or how your country works: Germany for example sports rather accurate and well-powered guns - in turn theres some dangerous weakspots in many of the tanks bodies, which can get you killed quick, if you dont use cover well.     // Now. If youre just getting into this game yourself I could tell you a ton of things and you would forget most of it before you even started your first match. So here are some basics:    1. Choice of Nation. When you start out, know that each of the 5 Nations has its strengths and weaknesses. Here is a rough guestimation:  US: Many fast Tanks but often with weaker armor. If you start with their planes know that Monoplanes will almost never outturn Biplanes - they are often faster than Biplanes, though.  Germany: Their early tanks are Glass-cannons. Dont trust on your Panzer 3 & 4s armor too much, use cover and drive carefully. The Guns are often accurate and deadly - early HEAT-ammo is quite effective - especially on long range.  Russia: Thickly armored Tanks and often big guns make deadly combos. Some consider them overpowered. Their early Biplanes (I-15) are also very deadly and outturn almost any plane. Their guns can be somewhat inaccurate, though.  UK: Rather durable planes with lots of deadly guns - less maneuverable than other nations, though. I havent had much time with their newly introduced tanks, yet, but they seem to have medium armor at best, quick reloads and good damage but horrible accuracy.   Japan: Their planes are quick and nimble - but also very fragile. A few salvos and you break apart and/or catch fire. As of now they dont have any tanks introduced to the game - history tells us they werent that great with tanks and had plans to buy tank-tech from germany.    2. 'If you die too much, hang back!' No really - You probably want to reasearch all the planes and tanks - but feel free to hang back at the beginning of matches and watch where your teammates go and where the enemy is. Being aware of the map and where everyone is is your >key to success<. (No really, it is!)    3. Watch that 'Battle Rating' Warthunder lacks a bit in introducing you about its mechanics. Every Vehicle has its 'Battle rating' you can see when you hover over it with your mouse. Know that the highest battlerating of all the tanks in your bottom-row at the mainscreen - the ones you go into battle with - determines what opponents you will face. If you slot in newer, better tanks with higher Battle-ratings, your opponents will also be stronger.  Knowing that you sometimes might want to wait after researching a tank, before you let it take the place of one of your older ones. I would say: Have at least one more of a similar Rank. 0.3 points higher or lower.    Finally - play with friends, join a clan or just start a group ingame by chatting people up. If you can use Teamspeak or Skype to talk it will be even better - and you will get an advantage over your opponents. Teamplay really helps!

A development team that has no idea what the community wants and makes a bunch of ridiculous changes that are neither wanted nor needed, then ignoring any requests to fix them. Great fun! Although the Steam page for this game says it has a singleplayer mode, much of it is pay-to-unlock. The game shines at its multiplayer with greatly optimized controls and network latency.   Being a free-to-play brings concerns that it might be pay-to-win, and it certainly is at some points. But with the matchmaking you generally get into a match with people who have the same skill and rank level as you - and that keeps the game fair.  Overall if you are looking for a flight fighting - sim or arcade - this is a game you should not miss.

The superior war machine simulator out there and its free! The amazing graphical capabilities go along well with Gaijin's effort to make the gameplay mechanic realistic especially, in aerial battles. From the aspect of immersion for a WWII and cold war military vehicle admirer, I say I recommend this game. At least take it out for a free ride with friends after binge watching some aviation films.  This game however, might be a huge waste of your computer space because of a number of ridiculous features which typically tag along with any free-to-play games. Dying to fly in the Spitfire or the BF109? Wanting to jump in command of a Tiger tank? Heres your life sentence condemned to the exp grinding mine. Unless of course, you pay up and obtain a shower of special exclusively premium vehicles and booster packs, making your life and your crews' substantially easier on the battlefield.  Lastly, the non-existent paywall could be heaven or hell for you depending on your randomly selected teammates in each round and their squad of vehicles. The Battle Rating or BR system basically doesn't care about your puny Panzer II and will definitely drop a few Russian KVs or some higher tier vehicles in on both sides, hopefully. Basically, once in every one or two Arcade games, you might just unfortunately end up as a free exp buffet for the opposing team and if you do care about winning, its going to be frustrating to fight unfair and uphill.

War Thunder was not something I would normally play, I am neither a WW2 fighter sim player, favouring more FPS style games. A few friends said to try this, having not enjoyed World of Planes. I did not regret it one bit! Easily one of the best games I've played recently, and it was a real tough decision to come away from this, to try Titanfall Beta, and a few other games I've had burning to complete. I still keep coming to this though, if you have a group of friends and a spare Teamspeak server, group up and have a laugh one night or weekend. The planes are beautifully detailed and no detail is missed, even when in a dog dight with other players. I'm also hesitant to play F2P games, having been burned in the past. War Thunder unlocks so much, and allows almost a full product right out the door. The research time and stat updates to your plane, can make for long hours between games, min/maxing, but you'll soon get the hang of it. 9/10 game for me!

I enjoy WW2 games , whether FPS or RTS , so this game was right up my alley. I always read game reviews before considering to get a game and i saw many people mainly complained on the Russian Bias , which is kinda true but Honestly you can just ignore them. The game is awesome, there is many historicly accurate depicted planes and tanks , the models are great. There are currently 5 factions to chose which offer different styles of play and their own advantages and disadvantages for example , American tank destroyers are quite easy to get early and carry a brutal punch while their beginning tanks are kinda bad compared to other early tier tanks , russian T34's have Great sloped armor and a hard hitting 76mm but a noticeable flaw is that its ammo racks are situated in the front and if you get a lucky shot , you can cause internal combustion. Germany have Decent beginning tanks such as the Pzkfw IV and III but all have short barreled guns and are weak until you get the long barreled version such as the G models , the same apply with their tank destroyers , the Stug . These are just some differences , there are many more . Overall the game is very fun and you dont have to grind that much which was surprising (as of this review being written , i have over 20 tanks and 10 planes without putting in cash . If you do put money in , dont spend on stupid cosmetics like bushes (which costs 20$ , 20 DOLLARS! for a virtual bush for your virtual tank) rather use it to speed up research points . I made this review as honest and realiable as i could and i hope you find it useful .

You might remember seeing a similar game with the name 'Wings of Prey'. That happens because the company is the same and most likely so is the game engine. That game was a great WW2 airplane combat simulator and War Thunder also is, but this time with tanks added to the mix.  Pros: + WW2 simulator. WW2 combat simulators are never enough. + Has arcade mode for those who prefer a 'WoT-alike' experience but with further 'realism' (will explain later) and better mechanics (because tanks having HP is lazy) + Tank customization the way it should be + Great graphics + Low graphics requirements for the cheaper computers + Free game  *The 'realism' is very debatable, because most people (should) know that german tanks and airplanes were the best in the WW2, while russia had cheap, fast and easy to build tanks and the other allies had numbers and strategy on their side. In this game however that can not happen because everyone would be driving Tiger tanks or piloting japanese fighters. Adding to this there something called 'russian bias', which will be pointed next.   Cons: - Rammers. People don't know how to shoot anymore, ramming the enemy fighter is WAY easier, specially if you have a crappy low tier fighter and want to take down a godlike high tier fighter/bomber. - Russian bias (although I have a doubt here because I've never seen russian airplanes/tanks consistently owning everyone like most people claim to have seen). What I have seen though is that the ones that usually do that are russian players, so can we really blame them for being good? Russians are the european version of asians, they are good, and they rarely play anything other than russian planes/tanks. - Tanks feel too fragile some times... A heavy tank CAN be destroyed in one hit if: 1º- You don't know what you are doing, heavy tanks are not invencible; 2º- The attacker knows what he's doing. Most tanks have weakspots and smart players WILL exploit them until you are dead! It's all down to skill and knowledge.    The most common Cons I see and why I think they are wrong: ~ Pay to Win: No. Just... No. I own premium airplanes and they are shot down as easily as other airplanes, and do as well as other airplanes. I NEVER use the premium airplanes I own because they are worse than my normal fighters. I can test drive premium tanks and they are as effective as normal tanks, sometimes the weakspots of premium tanks are even larger than on the 'normal' version. Just because some guy had a hard time fighting rocket launcher tanks it doesn't mean they are OP, they are just as bad as all other tanks, just don't pick paper-armor tanks and don't be afraid to push your barrel agaisnt it's hull. ~ Spawn-killing: For this to happen you are either losing HARD or you/your team has no idea how to play the game. Learn to play and defend your positions. Lack of skill CAN'T be replaced by blaming map layouts. ~ Battle Rating making russian tanks more OP: My KV-1 has been killed by a german medium tank in one shot. BR of both tanks was the same (KV-1 had 0.1 or 0.2 less). The next match the same happened with my T-50. Learn to play and stop blaming the russians.  TL:DR on the common complaints - This game is ALL ABOUT SKILL.  Also, do not try to blame the game for any difficulty you have because the biggest problem is between the screen and the chair, not in the code.

I've played this game for a very long time and im still playing it! For people who are interested in world war aircraft and people who just want to shoot stuff, this is the game for you. I learnt most of what I know about ww2 era planes from this game.

For a free to play game, it stuns me. in other FTP titles paying customers, more often then not feel overpowered. In this game there is none of that. Any money you decide to pay goes toward passive bonuses, such as research credit money or golden eagles. The flight models and plane hitboxes' nail a sense of realism. Not only that but in games such as World of Tanks, higher tiered vehicles will have an alarming advantage against lower. In this game should your aim be true, a biplane could kill a jet. Anyone can kill you. This adds a level of concentration that other games, time after time fail to provide. Such games as COD you can go out guns a blazing and top a leader board. Such stunts are rare in occurence. With over 200+ plane models and soon to be available are the ground forces extension. This includes the tanks of WW1 WW2 and the korean war. With challenges realised on the odd occasion based on real events, prevents this game from repetition as every plane will handle differently from the last. Gaijin has created a marvel that should be enjoyed and expireneced by all pc gaming.

Conceptually, a grand idea. 3 levels: Arcade, Realistic and Simulation. It is free to play, but if you want to avoid hte long grind you can buy your way to different levels of aircraft and armour.   The flight side of War Thunder is quite diverse and really provides some entertainment value if you like flying and historical aircraft.   Ground Forces however, is a different story. The basic metrics compared to historical data are far from correct. They are working on balancing matters, but it is far from desireable. The high end graphics are phenominal... however it decreases your visibility significantly. The developers have designed the game so the graphics level can accomidate your computer if its low end or seen it's time pass. The issue being those with high end devices run the lower graphics settings to allow for greater visibility at distance, which is a big plus in this game. Really, that amount of resources they must have invested in the spectacular landscape and maps could be diverted to other pressing matters. I am not the only one... watch the streams and see how many people show maps which are minimalisitc when it comes to foliage. Driving through the tall fields of wheat is epic... for the 1st minute of the match till someone one shots you as they have a significant view range advantage.  Another issue is spawn camping. Nothing more frustrating when you have the ability to respawn during a match and before you can even place your vehicle in gear you're destroyed. And sim these matches are mainly pugs... it really drags down the ability of good players if the team is not the best or lack experience.   If you have no desire upon winning or losing, commanding your own vehicle can be quite exciting... If you're frustrated by imbalance and ongoing issues, try one of the other tank sims.  Personally I play it as I like the 1st person command level and have invested some RL money into it. But as time has gone buy, the frustration level stops me from spending any more real life dollars here until they can provide a better sense of game balance, resolve the graphics issue and spawn camping.   Update.. as if the 1.51 patch matters worsen. The spawn camping is the ultimate fail for this game. Why allow multiple respawns when there are always a few whom sit outside the spawn area and sink shots into you soon as you spawn? I know there is a difference between getting basically over run and 3/4 of the opposing team is sitting at your spawn. It's when one or two go all the way around the map border then sit right off the spawn location(s).  I'll still play, but never more will spend any real $$ on this game. Watch twitch... you'll see the number of players on WoT outnumber this 500 to 1. Also, when someone like Jingles announces on Youtube that Gaijin has been taking down his commets due to the point he was pointing out the negative aspects and one sidedness in this game, that is the icing on the cake.  Update 1.5.5 December 2015 They have been about things, making some changes.  - Low end grahics They have introduced a new engine and it seems about 80% of the issues have cleared up with the visibility 'cheat'. Nice work - Spawn camping It now seems that when you rez you're invulnerable for a certain amount of time. Helpful. - Balance I guess the trendy would say Russian bias. However they have introduced the British line and they at this point in time are OP. Play them and you'll win 80% of the time. I tired 30 games the other day, 15 German, 15 Russian. As a German I was on one winning team. As a Russian I only lost 1 match.  - Marketing... egads... they need to be sacked and hire some people whom address the wants of the customers.

Free-to-play and fantastic leveling system as well as gametype matching make this dogflight simulator a must-have for any fan of aeronautics!  Edit: The new tier and leveling system released today (12/19/2013) with patch: 1.37. Not too sure if I enjoy the new leveling and tiering system, because you REALLY have to decide which planes you want before you buy or even research them. As well, it seems to take a LONG time to acquire new planes. You seem to be able to fully upgrade 2 or 3 planes that you own before you can buy any new ones. I do enjoy the new tiering system, and the matchmaking is even faster than before, and the planes are much more organized in the research tab. Still don't like that the squad maximum is only 4. Interesting game so far; can't wait to see what lies down the road from here, with the tank forces in beta, and naval forces on their tail!  Re: Edit: (04 Jan, 2014) I am not enjoying this game nearly as much as I used to. The whole leveling up and plane purchasing system is unusual and still confusing to me. I don't like the way the planes are mushed together into 5 tiers instead of 20. More often than not, I find myself facing much stronger opponents with much stronger guns and armor from the same tier as myself. I am still playing this game, but only because I have friends I enjoy playing with. Not too interested to see the tanks or the battleships. Don't even want to recommend this game anymore.  Re: Re: Edit: (14 Jan, 2014) Another update, more unengaging gameplay. I am glad they fixed the ability of a tier 3 bomber to end a game in approximately 4 minutes (looking at you, Yer-2's), but am discouraged of the reduction of lions and research points awarded to bombers for doing their job (bombing). I don't even want to play if any of my friends are not on. It simply isn't fun. This research system just stretches out how long it takes you to get to the planes you want, and they even increased the points on some of the planes that i've already unlocked the ability to purchase, requiring me to re-research them some more in order to buy and fly. I had high hopes for this game, but everything they are doing seems to make little to no sense, as they try to exploit those willing to pay-to-play, and punish those who do not.  Re: Re: Re: Edit: (19, Apr, 2014) Finally! An update that makes sense! Thank you for lowering research point values on EVERYTHING! Lower planes was nice, and the lower modifications feels feels like a bonus!. Hopefully now I can play some catch-up to some of my friends. However, not a big fan of not being able to skip planes anymore. If I don't want something, why do I have to research and buy it to get something else I want underneath? Otherwise, I can't wait for the tanks. Tally HO!

This is how you do free to play. War Thunder is by far the best WWII multiplayer flight simulator one can find right now. I would also wager it's one of if not, the best, WWII armored warfare game one can find. Also I should point out that while I say its a WWII game, it has usable content into the 1950's era for aircraft and tanks. For the most part though, you'lll find yourself playing in the era of the second world war. That is unless you decide its worth your money and time to either purchase premium time or a premium aircraft (I recommend it). It's not perfect and you'll find its flaws like you will any game, but if you have an interest in things flying, tanking, or WWII, then this game deserves some attention.  It's bound to only get better when VR becomes more mainstream.

I would recommend this prior to patch 1.37. However, with the current state of the game, I would not recommend it to new players due to the unfair Match Making forcing new players to face far better preforming planes from older players. Players who came prior to 1.37 also has a significant plane advantage which means a lot for arcade mode. New players will have to grind each plane individually while older players did not. In terms of unlocking new planes, it has been proven multiple times by players that the grind has increased over 250% even with the current patches.   Base bombing has been ruining arcade games since 1.37 while battles ending in less the 5 minutes even with the newest patch. Finally, the communication between the DEV's and the players is absolutely horrid, with little information about changes, fixes and solutions on problems.   As for Realistic Battles, many planes have current broken flight model's such as engine over-heating bugs which causes significant disadvantages. Finally, most Realistic Battles have more bots then actual players and these bots have broken flight model's allowing them to pull off feats that would be impossible otherwise.

The potential for the game is here. With the most aircraft available of any flying sim ever, and the devs 'trying' to make it as close to real life as possible, it's definitly worth checking out. There's also a tank mode, worth checking out for the novelty, but it will get bland fast due to this mode not being finished yet.  THE PROS: Loads of airplanes with each their own flight model to try out, there's planes for the USA, Germany, Soviet Russia, Britian, Japan, and in lesser extent Italians.  With 3 modes to choose from, being arcade, realistic battle, and sim mode, there's a gamemode for everyone.  New content being added by patches every so often  THE CONS: don't let this scare you away, at it's core it's a really great game, however, it hasn't quite reached it's full potential yet, here's why:  The grind sucks, like really really sucks, at higher tiers, when you think you've finally completed all aircraft, get prepared for an even longer grind for plane modules to make your aircraft even remotely capable.  Unbalance, again, at higher tiers you will have 1944 aircraft flying against post war aircraft and jets.  Dev team unresponsive/not listening to community. This is the main factor for me. Many people have ideas how to make the game better in their way, and of course, some of these ideas are crazy and not possible. But when an entire gaming community complains at once about certain aspects of the game, and nothing is really done, that's going to be a real negative.  All in all, it's still a great game, don't take the grind too seriously, because you will get frustrated, instead, just try and play for fun, and suddenly the game seems a lot better, yes, it has it's issues, but there's not much to be done. We can only hope our suggestion's/complaint's/bug reports will reach the dev's someday.

I have played 100+ hours of this game and i think i can say with some certainty that this game offers a great experience for those that love air-battles. (i'm personally not really into tank-battles) The planes feel really responsive and each have their own characteristics that make them turn, roll and shoot different from each other.     The tech-tree is interesting as it makes the planes/tanks less powerful when you first obtain it. After playing enough battles (and earning enough research-points) you can max it out and get the best version of that particular tank/plane. In my opinion, it's sometimes a bit tedious, but compared to getting new planes unlocked, it's a lot faster and more rewarding. also, it makes advancing through the ranks to get better planes a little bit more fun (since, you generally are not really paying attention to that due to the slow pace of getting new planes/tanks unlocked).   Gaijin Entertainment is frequently launching new tournaments that involve specific planes and tanks in which you can obtain limited edition of said planes (which usually costs lots of premium currency). The only drawback of this is that most of these tournaments involve planes/tanks of rank 3-5. Seeing that there are currently 5-6 different factions to choose from (and obtain planes/tanks from), you have to have put in a lot of effort to make sure you can participate in every tournament that is held.   This game has a free-to-play model and with this model comes certain limitations. To actually make profit, Gaijin Entertainment used premium currency and a subscription-service. The premium currency is called 'Golden Eagles' and is exactly as one would think: you can buy premium services, like extra crews, boosters, premium planes, etc. The subscription model gives you more regular currency (silver lions) and more research points. In all honesty, i can't review this specific part of the game, since i haven't invested real-life currency into this game.  In conclusion, would recommend if you like to have dogfights in WOII settings.

I highly recommend anyone with an interest in history, flying, tanks and ships try this game. The new 1.39 Patch has fixed a lot of things and made the game highly appealing to new starters. The game features aircraft ranging from 1930-1950s taking you from spanish civil war to the korean war and the game currently features 6 nations which are USA, Great Britain, Soviet Union, Germany (Italy is currently classed under germany but devs have plans to add them as a full faction later) and Japan. With Tanks soon out this year and warships soon to follow after tanks  The game has 3 gamemodes/flight models   ARCADE is for people who aren't fussed and just want to have fun featuring multiple respawns  REALISTIC features more realism such as engine overheating and the planes wings ripping off if you increase in speed. features one plane when you lose it you must wait for the match to end  FULLY REALISTIC BATTLE this mode disables third person camera and you are confined to your planes cockpit and must scan the skies manually like the aviators of yore.  The game is fully free to pay with the option to buy certain planes but these are rendered useless unless you know how to utilise them to their full effectiveness. There is very little buy to win here as anything can be countered if you have the correct tactics  I won't give it a rating number as I find that system silly but this game has brought me many hours of joy and I hope I have conveyed that whether an interest in flight, history or the wars spanning 1930-1950 I highly recommend everyone try this game.

This game is a fantastic aerial combat simulator that allows the player to pilot a wide range of planes (and tanks) from the WWII era from 5 major contenders of WWII: The Americans, the Germans, the USSR, the British (planes only), and the Japanese (planes only). There are three modes of play: Arcade, realistic, and simulator, each much more complicated than the last. Your goal is to either wipe out every remaining plane on the enemy team, bomb out the enemy team's base or destroy their ground units, or for tanks it may be capturing a position for your team to achieve victory instead.  Either way, YOU WILL HAVE FUN. I assure you, there is NOTHING more satisfying than setting a plane on fire in an intense dogfight involving literally, LITERALLY, 12 people.  That being said, it has a major learning curve. The great thing is you have 5 completely different countries with 5 completely different sets of planes. So many choices!  I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME. VERY, VERY HIGHLY.

AMAZING GAME. A simple mouse and keyboard setup can be used for planes, not just tanks. I use a mouse, keyboard, and joystick setup for planes, using the keyboard for both advanced control (flaps, landing gear, etc.) and rudder control. You don't need to have a pilot's license to learn to fly in this. A child could do this. But at the came time, it's advanced as the most realistic flight simulator out there. By not overwhelming you with gauges and buttons, plus the ability to map out keys, it's easy to fly. Not only that, but it teaches you about planes, tanks, and prototypes of them. No flaws exist as far as I know.

The good: -Three diffrent gamestyles: arcade, realistic(my favourite) and simulator. -Nice vehicle models. -Combined arms air and tanks in same match. -Every vehicle in game has unique feeling of drive. -Nice grapchics. -NO HP system(hahah in your face WOT(I never played it so I wont go anyway)).  The bad: -Battle rating is not fully balanced. -AP shells are underperforming. -M61/M82 shells also underperforming. -AF battles are too short because of 4 bombers can finnish game in 5mintues. -GF battles only have 2 maps where you need aim higher 2km range. -Bombers dont have cockpit. -Very rare nigh battles.   The UGLY: -Russian tanks tooooooo much overperforming. -Russian airplanes toooooo much overperforming. -Russian tanks shell also tooooo much overperforming. -YAK9, YAK3 are in tooo low battle rating. -For some USA tanks battle rating are tooo high. -For some USA airplanes battle rating are tooo high.  Game is great its worth time to play, but you need to learn how to achieve best of the best from your vehicle to achieve maximum performance and results.

After breaching the 400 hr playtime i would like to edit my review and update it.  Shocking news: I still highly recommend the game. Warthunders constant updates really keep the game interesting and fun to play.   Since my original review did not contain any criticism at all, these are the points which are on the negativ list:  1) You can not reach the highest tier of vehicles without a premium account. Yes it is possible, but for the average player having an average life including stuff like work for example it is not. The only way reaching tier V is to concentrate on one nation and one of element of the game (tanks or airplanes). But only playing one thing isnt really an option since you will miss a lot of interesting content.   2) Some nations are not beeing simulated historical correct to archieve a better balance. Some nations even seem to be buffed a bit. This is a bit disappointing if you are interested in the technology used in the war and would like to have an at least approximate experience using your virtual machine of war.  3) Just like its rival World of Tanks (and the other two) the prices are just crazy. But i guess we are all old enough to make a budget and keep ourselfs to the limits.

As you can tell this is totally a one hour review and i know nothing abut this game.   Let me start off by saying one thing- You will never find a WW2 Arcade or Full simulator as good as this, its beautiful, historically accurate and you're always learning something new.   Arcade mode is easy to play and great for everyone, the controls are simple and the gamemodes are fast paced.  Realistc offers a fun game mode for people who want something close o historical accuracy and a more realistic mode without the full restraints of a full simulator game, game modes make more sense and are more team driven.  Simulator is for the pilot who wants to go all out and challenge themselves, gamesmodes make perfect sense and are even based off real battles, the planes act realistically and you're forced into first person.  This game is great for everyone because of its sheer ease of access, playability, the fact that it's free, and the range of dificulty.

War Thunder is mostly positive in my opinion. It is one of the best simulator games I had played since it has tanks (Expecting ships for all factions and ground vehicles for Japan.) It takes a lot of space in your PC but you'll love it in the end.  HOWEVER, there are some points to be considered. If you start off as the UK on the army then you'll get the Teterach tank from the start. Whenever I drive it, it keeps on wriggling and just can't get it on the track unlike other vehicles. The same applies to the A13. You will experience AWFUL Package Loss, which can be fatal to your battle specially in air battles since you'll crash onto the ground when you were flying 3,000 KM up in the heavens a second ago. It'll be good if they can add Fairey Battle to the UK.  ***The developer also made Star Conflict which is a similar game but Sci-Fi. In the both games there are Premium currencies- Golden Eagles in WT, which can be used to purchase some premium vehicles, modifications (instantly), convert *convertible* RPs into RPs and buy Silver Lions. In Star Conflict you get repleshments of the Premium Currency by completing missions. However, in WT, you must use real money to buy these premium currencies (Golden Eagles) ...still I appreciate that this game is free.***  Apart from that, this game is largely recommended by me anyways. Installation will take long but it'll be worth it. Just play it to try it out, if you don't like it then uninstall it- you wouldn't have to spend a penny afterall. Be sure to complete all tutorials and collect rewards since they are wonderful and have a good battle, Pilots and Tankers!!!
